channel.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
channel.description: What is the laws covering polices ability to search you in a public place (QLD) Also what is the best plan of action against intimidating police.

item.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

What do you honestly expect them to do? Is it right? Perhaps not, but you’ve got over 15 offenses before the age of 18.

What the fuck?

Read full topic

item.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Zaromix:

So if I asked a police officer of their rank and they were below an inspector they can’t search me either way?

sorry, I would not recommend doing this, I was mistaken when I said this

a police of the rank inspector or higher is requires to perform a cavity search, as far as I’m aware any police officer can do a regular ‘pat down’ search

again I am not a lawyer, if you want solid legal advise I suggest you go see one

Read full topic

item.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

Zaromix:

Ok buddy, you don’t know who I am, what walk of life I’m from or anything about me. If you want to know the truth I’m a good person. I’ve fallen into the wrong crowd in the past and now I’m paying for it. For starters it’s not your country you imbecile. It’s just as much mine as it is yours and you really seem like an uneducated neanderthal. Coming here being all macho acting like you run the place. Suck up your little pre-pubescent balls and walk away. There are many different people in this country and I’m far from and scum… Maybe if you have such a problem you can go live in your own little fantasy world where people don’t steal or break any laws for that matter. All I’m trying to do is protect my rights as a citizen from these corrupt power abusing motherloveers. If you knew shit from tuesday you’d realize how much of a mess the QLD police are… They are the #1 most corrupt police force in Australia and I’m forced to put up with their bullshit intimidation, lies and twisting of the truth, they are in the wrong not me… They are the loveing criminal not me… Come to think of it they are just one big joke and you are supporting them with your ignorant stupidity.

  1. Thanks for the wall of text. I would have had more fun poking at my eyes with needles than reading your dribble.

  2. I don’t know what you’ve been through? I can promise you that I’ve seen a lot more of that bullshit than you have in my time.

  3. Just as much your country as mine? Not if you don’t respect the place and it’s laws. Especially the police, who work amazingly hard to protect people. Dealing with scum like you would irritate me.

You’re the ignorant one I’m afraid. I suggest you grow up and pull your head in. The world isn’t against you, stop playing the victim. You’re the joke ‘buddy’. Usually i would type up some long novel, pointing out every way you’ve proven that you’re an idiot. However, I think that you’ve managed to do that yourself.

Read full topic

item.source: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them

item.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Zaromix:

What if you’re approached for a search before any criminal history is even subject to the matter, also what if this criminal history is not on my “record” so to speak, i.e. no conviction recorded.

so lets break this down, despite having a legal right to resist an unlawful search or arrest, if the search was lawful then refusing to comply you will likely face much more severe charges than what the alleged probable cause would find, such as this

so, what constitutes an unlawful search or arrest? when there is no probable cause, so, what is probable cause defined as? that’s the problem, probable cause in most countries isn’t rigidly defined and a bunch of laws (such as drug laws) don’t help the case, probable cause can apply to damn near every situation which is why most law advise websites will advise against resisting a search or arrest (note: only an inspector or above can perform a search in Australia, but please for the love of god this is not legal advise I am not a lawyer)

what your situation does sound like may be considered harassment so I really do suggest you take a visit to a citizens advise bureau or a lawyer if you want to see if there’s something to do about it, such as making a formal complaint (citizens advise bureaus over here in the UK are free and I imagine the same is true for Australia)

since you said you have resisted arrest before and the police do know who you are then yes they do have probable cause

Read full topic

item.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

you’d be best off consulting the citizens advise bureau for what to do during a stop and search and whether or not it’s police harassment (given that you’re a minor) but yeah, a criminal history is definitely probable cause for a crime

Read full topic
item.source: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them

item.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
item.dc:creator: @Zaromix Zaromix
item.description:
@Zaromix wrote:

Thanks for the link, I was having a really hard time locating anything with some good reliable information that isn’t extremely generalized. Does anyone have an idea of what I could say to them next time I get randomly stopped for a search while walking through the area?

EDIT: Also would previous offences affect whether they have probable cause to do the search or not? Whether they be a caution for a previous drug offence (tiny amount of marijuana) or criminal offences while I was a minor (still a minor [16]) criminal offences include 14 counts of break and enter when i was in grade 9 and there was unlawful use of a motor vehicle earlier this year when i was 15 (stealing a car) and also obstructing police by trying to out run them on foot if it matters what offences they are.

Read full topic
item.source: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them

item.title: Australian Police Rights and your rights against them
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

http://www.aussielegal.com.au/informationoutline~nocache~1~SubTopicDetailsID~819.htm

although you legally can, the absolute worse thing you could attempt to do would be to resist the search

if you get in touch with your citizens advise bureau and explain the situation they should be able to help you make a formal complaint

Read full topic
